head.title: To Find a New Killer Attack, Try Renovating an Old One

hedline.hl1: To Find a New Killer Attack, Try Renovating an Old One

abstract.p: Robert Byrne column notes that National Chess Congress, held in Philadephia from Nov 22 to 28, finished with four-grandmaster tie for first place; says Joel Benjamin, Aleksandr Goldin, Alexander Shabalov and Alexander Ivanov were each awarded $1,425; diagram (M)

block.p: The National Chess Congress, held in Philadelphia from Nov. 22 to 28, finished with a four-grandmaster tie for first place. Joel Benjamin of Manhattan, Aleksandr Goldin of Russia, Alexander Ivanov of Brookline, Mass., and Alexander Shabalov of Pittsburgh each scored 5-1 in the 84-entrant, Swiss-system event and each was awarded a prize of $1,425. No tiebreak coefficients were used. The tournament, run by the Continental Chess Association, was held at the Adam's Mark Hotel.

The National Chess Congress, held in Philadelphia from Nov. 22 to 28, finished with a four-grandmaster tie for first place. Joel Benjamin of Manhattan, Aleksandr Goldin of Russia, Alexander Ivanov of Brookline, Mass., and Alexander Shabalov of Pittsburgh each scored 5-1 in the 84-entrant, Swiss-system event and each was awarded a prize of $1,425. No tiebreak coefficients were used. The tournament, run by the Continental Chess Association, was held at the Adam's Mark Hotel.

The gem of the first round -- and possibly of the entire tourney -- was the encounter between Goldin and Dean Ippolito of Boontown, N.J. The Russian sharpened up a recently resuscitated attack and won impressively.

After 5 . . . h6 in the Semi-Slav Variation, the once discredited gambit with 6 Bh4! is currently a hot item. For many years now, the positional 6 Bf6 Qf6 has held the field, but in a Ruck-Szuhanek game in Zalakaros, Hungary, 7 e3 Nd7 8 Bd3 Qd8 9 0-0 Be7 10 a3 0-0 11 Qc2 b6!? 12 cd ed 13 b4 Bb7 14 Qb3 Nf6 15 Rfe1 Rb8!? 16 Ne5 Bd6 17 f4 c5 18 bc bc 19 Qa4 a6 worked well for Black.

After 6 . . . dc 7 e4 g5 8 Bg3 b5 9 Be2, defense with 9 . . . Bb7 has failed against 10 h4 g4 11 Ne5 b4?! 12 Na4 Ne4 13 Bc4 h5 14 Qe2 Ng3 15 fg Rh6 16 O-O f5 17 d5! Qa5 18 Rf5!, with an annihilating attack in a Stohl-Pavasovic game in Portoroz, Yugoslavia, in June.

Moreover, the alternative with 9 . . . Nbd7 has not held up against 10 d5! For instance, 10 . . . b4 11 de bc 12 ed Bd7 13 bc Ne4 14 Qd4 Ng3 15 hg Rg8 16 Qc4 has stuck Black with problems defending his king, as in a Belyavsky-Atalik game in Vrnjacka Banja, Yugoslavia, in October. So Ippolito tried to keep a more compact formation with 9 . . . Bb4.
After 10 Qc2 g4 11 Ne5 Qd4 12 O-O Bc3 13 bc Qe4, Ippolito was three pawns ahead, but Goldin was about to renovate an old, nearly forgotten onslaught.

After 14 . . . Nbd7, Max Euwe suggested 33 years ago that White would get a dangerous attack with 15 Rad1, which was probably anticipated by Ippolito, but now Goldin steps up the attack another notch with 15 f3!, after which 15 . . . Qd5 16 Qf4 Ne5 17 Qe5 Qe5 18 Be5 Ke7 19 fg will cost Black a piece.
Ippolito avoided that with 16 . . . Rg8, but after 17 Nd7 Nd7 18 fg e5 19 Qh6, Goldin was only a pawn down, for which he had an overwhelming attack.

After 24 . . . Kc7, Goldin scored with 25 Rd7! Rd7 26 Qe5 Kd8 (or 26 . . . Rd6 27 Bc5 Rg8 28 Rf6) 27 Bg4 f5 28 Bf5 Qg7 29 Qb8 Bc8 (or 29 . . . Ke7 30 Bc5 Kf7 31 Bd7) 30 Bd7. If 30 . . . Qd7, then 31 Bd4 Re8 32 Bf6 Re7 33 Re1. Ippolito gave up.
